metadata.title: Frequency of human bocavirus (HBoV) infection among children with febrile respiratory symptoms in Argentina, Nicaragua and Peru

abstract.original_text: Background Globally, respiratory infections are the primary cause of illness in developing countries, specifically among children; however, an etiological agent for many of these illnesses is rarely identified.

sentences.segment_text: Background Globally , respiratory infections are the primary cause of illness in developing countries ,
an etiological agent for many of these illnesses is rarely identified .

abstract.original_text: Objectives Our study aimed to estimate the frequency of human bocavirus (HBoV) infection among pediatric populations in Argentina, Nicaragua and Peru.

sentences.segment_text: Objectives Our study aimed to estimate the frequency of human bocavirus ( HBoV ) infection among pediatric populations in Argentina , Nicaragua and Peru .

abstract.original_text: Methods We conducted a cross-sectional study using stored samples of an influenza-like illness surveillance program. Irrespective of previous diagnosis, nasopharyngeal or nasal swab specimens were randomly selected and tested using real-time PCR from three sites during 2007 from patients younger than 6 years old.

sentences.segment_text: Methods We conducted a cross-sectional study using stored samples of an influenza-like illness surveillance program .
Irrespective of previous diagnosis , nasopharyngeal or nasal swab specimens were randomly selected and tested using real-time PCR from three sites during 2007 from patients younger than 6 years old .

abstract.original_text: Results A total of 568 specimens from Argentina (185), Nicaragua (192) and Peru (191) were tested. The prevalence of HBoV was 10AE8% (95% CI: 6AE3; 15AE3) in Argentina, 33AE3% in Nicaragua (95% CI: 26AE6; 40AE1) and 25AE1% in Peru (95% CI: 18AE9; 31AE3). Conclusions These findings demonstrate circulation of HBoV in Argentina, Nicaragua and Peru among children with influenza-like symptoms enrolled in a sentinel surveillance program. Keywords Epidemiology, human bocavirus, respiratory illness. Please cite this paper as: Salmó n-Mulanovich et al. (2011) Frequency of human bocavirus (HBoV) infection among children with febrile respiratory symptoms in Argentina, Nicaragua and Peru. Influenza and Other Respiratory Viruses 5(1), 1-5.

sentences.segment_text: Results A total of 568 specimens from Argentina ( 185 ) ,
The prevalence of HBoV was 10AE8 % ( 95 % CI : 6AE3 ; 15AE3 ) in Argentina ,
33AE3 % in Nicaragua ( 95 % CI : 26AE6 ; 40AE1 ) and 25AE1 % in Peru ( 95 % CI : 18AE9 ; 31AE3 ) .
Conclusions These findings demonstrate circulation of HBoV in Argentina ,
Nicaragua and Peru among children with influenza-like symptoms enrolled in a sentinel surveillance program .
Keywords Epidemiology , human bocavirus , respiratory illness .
Please cite this paper as : Salmó n-Mulanovich et al. ( 2011 ) Frequency of human bocavirus ( HBoV ) infection among children with febrile respiratory symptoms in Argentina , Nicaragua and Peru .
